importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Date of incident involving Pastor David Black being hit with pepper balls during a protest in Chicago’s Albany Park neighborhood.
Date of the hearing where U.S. District Judge Sara Ellis pressed federal officials on their response to protests in Chicago during Operation Midway Blitz.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Period during which Operation Midway Blitz led to over 1,000 arrests of migrants across Illinois, marking the scope of federal enforcement activity in Chicagoland.

keyTakeAways: Judge Sara Ellis issued a temporary restraining order restricting federal agents' use of force and crowd control tactics during protests in Chicago, expanding it to require body-worn cameras for agents on the ground.
CBP agents in Chicago (over 200) are required to use body-worn cameras, while ICE Special Response Teams have not been issued cameras and would need Congressional approval to obtain them.
ICE agents are trained in protest response, arrest procedures, and handling journalists, with specific protocols to protect media presence during demonstrations.

A pastor, Rev. David Black, reported being hit with pepper balls without warning during a protest in Albany Park, claiming he was outside the facility praying and did not leave federal property when ordered to do so.

Federal leadership in the Chicago area has been described as a 'revolving door', with frequent changes in high-level officers such as Russell Hott, who left the Chicago field office to return to Washington, DC.
The Trump administration has denied reports of tear gas use without warning during protests, though ICE leadership reviews all force incidents through internal review committees.

Judge Ellis will continue to depose Russell Hott and Gregory Bovino, citing that Hott was the highest-ranking officer in Chicago at the time of the protests and thus capable of providing ground-level insight.

summaryOfNewsArticle: U.S. District Judge Sara Ellis is actively scrutinizing the federal government’s response to anti-immigration protests in Chicago during Operation Midway Blitz, a large-scale ICE enforcement campaign that resulted in over 1,000 arrests. In a hearing, she expanded her temporary restraining order to require body-worn cameras for federal agents on the ground, especially to address concerns about the use of tear gas and pepper balls without warning. CBP agents are equipped with cameras, while ICE Special Response Teams are not, and have faced criticism for their lack of equipment. The judge questioned both CBP and ICE officials about training, enforcement protocols, and transparency, particularly in light of a reported incident involving Pastor David Black being attacked without warning. Federal leadership has been described as a 'revolving door,' with key officers like Russell Hott leaving the Chicago area, prompting further depositions. The Trump administration has denied reports of tear gas use without warning, while internal reviews of force incidents are conducted by ICE leadership. The case underscores ongoing tensions between federal law enforcement, civil liberties, and media transparency during protests.
title: Judge Presses Federal Officials on Response to Chicago Protests
